description.plain:
Shéyaa Bin Abraham-Joseph, known professionally as 21 Savage, was born in the London Borough of Newham on October 22, 1992 to parents of  Dominican and Haitian descent. He and his mother moved to the United States when Savage was seven years old, residing in East Atlanta, Georgia. In June 2005, he briefly returned to the U.K. for his uncle’s funeral before quickly returning to the U.S. less than a month later on an H-4 visa.

Savage first gained musical notoriety after releasing the underground hit “Picky” in November 2014. The following year, he released three projects: The Slaughter Tape, Free Guwop, and Slaughter King.

After a massive 2015, Savage was included in the 2016 XXL Freshman Class. The cover was revealed on June 13, 2016. A month later, on July 15, 2016, Savage released Savage Mode, a collaborative EP with Metro Boomin.

On July 7, 2017, Savage released his debut studio album, Issa Album. Less than four months later, on October 31, 2017, he released Without Warning, a collaborative album with Offset and Metro.

On December 21, 2018, Savage released his sophomore studio album, i am > i was.

On February 3, 2019, Savage was arrested by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) for overstaying his visa, which initially expired in 2006. Before that, in 2017, Savage applied for a U visa so that he could remain in the United States. He was released on bond nine days later.

On October 2, 2020, 21 Savage and Metro Boomin reunited for their second collaborative album, SAVAGE MODE II.

He and his mother moved to the United States when Savage was seven years old, residing in East Atlanta, Georgia. In June 2005, he briefly returned to the U.K. for his uncle’s funeral before quickly returning to the U.S. less than a month later on an H-4 visa.

Savage first gained musical notoriety after releasing the underground hit “Picky” in November 2014. The following year, he released three projects: The Slaughter Tape, Free Guwop, and Slaughter King.

After a massive 2015, Savage was included in the 2016 XXL Freshman Class. The cover was revealed on June 13, 2016. A month later, on July 15, 2016, Savage released Savage Mode, a collaborative EP with Metro Boomin.

On July 7, 2017, Savage released his debut studio album, Issa Album. Less than four months later, on October 31, 2017, he released Without Warning, a collaborative album with Offset and Metro.

On December 21, 2018, Savage released his sophomore studio album, i am > i was.

On February 3, 2019, Savage was arrested by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) for overstaying his visa, which initially expired in 2006. Before that, in 2017, Savage applied for a U visa so that he could remain in the United States. He was released on bond nine days later.

On October 2, 2020, 21 Savage and Metro Boomin reunited for their second collaborative album, SAVAGE MODE II.

songs.title: Bank Account

description.plain:
“Bank Account” sees 21 Savage rapping about his wealth amongst other things over a dark beat produced by Metro Boomin and 21 Savage himself.

The track samples Coleridge-Taylor Perkinson’s 1974 song “Flashbulbs,” a sample also used on Travis Scott’s “Oh My Dis Side.”

On the 10th of November the music video was released, starring comedian Mike Epps and directed by Matt Swinsky.

songs.title: ​a lot

description.plain:
On the introspective introduction to his sophomore studio album, 21 Savage raps about having “a lot” of blessings and curses in his life. Savage also reflects on his tumultuous upbringing, his dangerous lifestyle, and the pain and loss he has suffered.

Savage calls on J. Cole to assist him on the track. In his verse, Cole reflects on his career, comments on the state of the music industry, and offers advice to other artists and athletes.

The song reached heightened popularity about a month after its release when Savage was arrested by the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) during ATL’s Super Bowl weekend. In the week leading up to his arrest, Savage unveiled an extended version of the track in which he criticizes the U.S.’s immigration policies on the country’s border with Mexico.

songs.title: ​ball w/o you

description.plain: On “ball w/o you,” 21 Savage reflects on multiple past relationships and realizes that he has become disillusioned with love, which he considers artificial. 21 prefers loyalty because he believes it demands a higher level of mutual respect than love.

songs.title: Immortal

description.plain:
On “Immortal,” 21 Savage raps about his murderous tendencies while also name-dropping characters in the Mortal Kombat video game series.

The song was previewed in the Mortal Kombat 11 trailer that was released on December 6, 2018. It was originally speculated to appear on 21’s second studio album, i am > i was, which released two weeks after the trailer. However, this did not occur, and the track’s release date was undetermined.

On August 10, 2019, 21 teased the song’s imminent release, tweeting:
https://twitter.com/21savage/status/1160333306333995008

The track was finally released on Halloween 2019, nearly eleven months after it was first teased.

songs.full_title: ​all my friends by 21 Savage (Ft. Post Malone)
songs.title: ​all my friends

description.plain:
On “all my friends,” 21 Savage and Post Malone reflect on their success and how it has affected their friendships. As they both gained wealth and fame, their respective relationships with envious people deteriorated.

While Post experienced this after his rise to fame, 21 sat down with Rob Markman on ‘For the Record’ and explained that he first began to lose friendships over money when he started getting “street” money, before his rap career.

songs.title: ​asmr

description.plain:
On “asmr,” 21 Savage recalls his whispering flow from November 2018’s “Don’t Come Out the House.”

The song is inspired by ASMR, which stands for ‘autonomous sensory meridian response.’ ASMR describes a feeling of euphoric tingling and relaxation that can come over someone when they hear incredibly quiet sounds, such as whispering, clicking, and chewing. ASMR YouTube channels had a significant rise in popularity in 2018.

21 first previewed this song on November 26, 2018.

songs.full_title: Issa (Original) by 21 Savage (Ft. Drake & Young Thug)
songs.title: Issa (Original)

description.plain:
“Issa” is a catchphrase coined by 21 Savage, first used in his interview with DJ Vlad—“Issa Knife” quickly became slang, and eventually became a meme.

https://twitter.com/21savage/status/826318937151373313

“Issa” was initially only a Young Thug and 21 Savage collaboration when the snippet was released, however, Drake was recruited for his input.

“Issa” was rumored to be called “Petty” or “Kylie Jenner” (in reference to 21’s crush on Kylie) before the official release.

On October 10, 2017, producer Bricks privately uploaded the full song in CDQ on his SoundCloud, but it was only publicly made available in late December. This newer version of the song features Bricks' production tag as well as additional adlibs from Young Thug.

songs.title: 4L

description.plain: This track is an ode to 21 Savage and Young Nudy’s shared “4L” gang. They both rap about their murderous lifestyles, specifically naming their many guns and ammunition. They also flex their wealth and sexual endeavors. 21 and Nudy have rapped about 4L throughout their careers.

songs.title: Nothin New

description.plain: 21 Savage gets political on “Nothin New,” voicing his frustrations with the system and systematic racism that black people in America face. The title reflects how blasé events like a shooting of a black man or a drop out have become, and how desensitized society has become to it.

songs.title: 7 Min Freestyle

description.plain: The final song on 21 Savage’s debut album “Issa Album”, 7 Minute Freestyle was previewed back on April 26th, 2017 as a snippet on Twitter. Produced by Southside and Metro Boomin, 21 Savage wastes no time diving into talking about his luxuries and money. As it progresses, he makes it clear that he’s still close to his roots even when he is incredibly successful. He used to be dangerous, but now he’s rich and dangerous. 21 Savage finishes off the song by dissing immature guys who depend on someone else for their money, telling them to get their own money.

description.plain:
After releasing his sophomore album on December 21st, 21 Savage surprise-dropped the sequel to “out for the night” three days later on 24 December 2018.

Like its prequel, “out for the night, pt. 2” samples Santana’s “Samba Pa Ti,” but features Billboard-topping rapper Travis Scott. The track is the only addition to the deluxe version of i am > i was.

songs.title: ​out for the night

description.plain:
“out for the night” is the fourth track off of 21 Savage’s sophomore album, i am > i was.  The songs contains a sample from Carlos Santana’s 1970 track “Samba Pa Ti”.

A sequel to this track, “out for the night, pt. 2”, was included as the only bonus track to the album’s deluxe edition, with an additional third verse by Travis Scott.

songs.title: Whole Lot

description.plain:
“Whole Lot” culminates the state of 21’s career at this very moment. He is getting the money he earns, but the superstar lifestyle has its problems.

A demo version of the song featuring a verse from Young Thug was leaked on May 30, 2018.

songs.title: FaceTime

description.plain:
“FaceTime” is a unique track on Issa Album as it is a departure from the common themes of the street hustle, tough upbringing, and violence that normally make up 21 Savage songs. Here, he is describing his feelings for a girl and their potential future together.

Days before the release of Issa Album, rumors placed 21 Savage to be dating Amber Rose.

songs.title: ​gun smoke

description.plain:
On “gun smoke,” 21 Savage makes his love and necessity for owning and using firearms crystal clear. Savage discussing themes of having a plethora of weapons is very common within his discography, which he addresses in the song’s first verse:

Savage, why you always rappin' ‘bout guns for? (Straight up)
'Cause, bitch, I fell in love with the gun smoke (Straight up)

While delivering raps about guns, Savage also obligatorily reps his home of East Atlanta and references the viral 2018 dance challenge started by Shiggy to Drake’s 2018 song, “In My Feelings.”

“gun smoke” was first previewed in a trailer exclusive to Spotify for RapCaviar’s i am > i was mini documentary alongside “monster” featuring Childish Gambino.

songs.title: Thug Life

description.plain:
“Thug Life” is an ode to the late hip-hop legend 2Pac. Regarded as one of hip-hop’s best artists of all time, Pac was a notorious gangster and had a prominent tattoo across his stomach that read “Thug Life.”



In 1993, Tupac formed a rap group called Thug Life that consisted of Tupac Shakur, Big Syke, Macadoshis, Stretch, The Rated R, and finally Tupac’s half brother Mopreme. Eventually, the Thug Life caught up with 2Pac on September 7, 1996 and he was shot four times in a drive-by shooting in Las Vegas, Nevada. Six days later, hip-hop lost one of the greatest artists it has ever witnessed.

In addition to referencing 2Pac, “Thug Life,” the sixth track on Issa Album, details 21’s drug-filled beginnings of him hiding crack at his grandmas house, his experience with an unfaithful girl and other dealings that all represent his thug lifestyle.

The song also samples “Giving Him Something He Can Feel,” a classic 90s r&b hit by En Vogue.

songs.title: Close My Eyes

description.plain:
On the third track of his latest album Issa Album, 21 Savage rationalizes his homicidal tendencies and grapples with the consequences of his trapping lifestyle.

There’s a certain game 21 has to play in order to succeed at trapping because to go against that game is suicide. What’s more is that if you aren’t the one murdering, then you are the one getting murdered. Add to that a traumatic childhood which leaves 21 asking God why all his friends had to die growing up, and you’ve got yourself a rationale for killing at least 5 enemy gang members and setting an entire block on fire. Not to mention, wasting the police who come to arrest him and his gang.

As a consequence for all of his actions, 21 sees dead bodies whenever he closes his eyes. He has to live with being the one that made the mothers of his victims cry. He also can’t get any sleep because he’s too high from having to deal with his PTSD.

Yet despite all of his suffering, all of these experiences make him the the last real rapper.

songs.title: Mind Yo Business

description.plain: The sixth track on the Slaughter King album, “Mind Yo Business” alludes to 21’s violent tendencies as evidenced by the graphic lyrics about drugs, guns and killing all over a downright evil and gloomy beat. The song concludes with a flurry of gun shots that artistically wraps up the song and its message, don’t get caught in 21’s way and mind yo business.

songs.title: ​pad lock

description.plain: On this somber track, 21 Savage raps about how, as a result of his difficult upbringing and criminal lifestyle, he has developed a cold heart. 21 has closed himself off to others, essentially putting a “pad lock” on his heart, because making money is more of a priority for him.

songs.title: Secret

description.plain:
“Secret” features 21 Savage taking a major stylistic and venturing into a lighter, sensual R&B track with the help of crooner Summer Walker. The two both talk about keeping their relationship with their significant others a secret, keeping their relationships for themselves and not opening it up to the public.

The song originally appeared online on February 24, 2020, before its official release on April 17, 2020.

songs.full_title: ​​a lot (Video Version) by 21 Savage (Ft. J. Cole)
songs.title: ​​a lot (Video Version)

description.plain:
The music video version of “a lot” follows the same structure of the original song with the addition of a new fourth verse from 21. In that verse, he continues many of the song’s original themes, except for the last few lines, in which he criticizes immigration policies on the United States’ border.

The verse was first discovered on physical versions of 21’s sophomore album, i am > i was, on December 31, 2018. When his management turned in the album for physical copies to be made, they turned in a solo version of the track, likely before Cole’s verse was fully completed. 21 revealed in his For the Record interview with Genius, which was recorded the day before the album dropped, that the song had only fully came together a few days before its release.

21 rapped the solo version of the track during his performance of “a lot” on Jimmy Fallon’s late-night show, which premiered on January 29, 2019. The verse then appeared three days later in the song’s music video, which included all verses. This is when most fans discovered it.
